thread.title: Jury in trial of Rolf Harris retires to consider verdicts
thread.title_full: Jury in trial of Rolf Harris retires to consider verdicts

author: Steve Cannane
title: Jury in trial of Rolf Harris retires to consider verdicts
text:
The jury in the Rolf Harris trial in London has retired to consider its verdicts. 
The 86-year-old has pleaded not guilty to six counts of indecent assault and one of sexual assault. 
The allegations involve seven women and girls aged 12 to 42 and are said to have taken place over a 33-year period beginning in 1971. 
Judge Alistair McCreath told the jury of five men and seven women that at this stage they were required to deliver a unanimous verdict. 
In summing up, Justice McCreath said the jury would be "entitled to consider how unlikely it would be for a number of women all unknown to each other to make similar allegations about the same man". 
In considering this, the judge also said the jury would have to weigh up whether the complainants had been influenced by similar allegations raised at Harris's 2014 trial. 
Harris is serving a sentence of five years and nine months at Stafford prison for previous convictions of indecent assault. 
During the latest trial these prior convictions have been admissible as evidence, as the prosecution attempted to portray the latest allegations as consistent with Harris's character and behaviour. 
Justice McCreath told the jury they should consider whether the evidence shows Harris has a propensity to indecently assault women. 
However the judge stressed that just because Harris has acted a certain way in the past, it did not mean he was guilty of the seven charges before the court. 
He said that widespread publicity surrounding the first trial had made his client "vulnerable to people making accusations against him". 
Mr Vullo urged the jury to acquit the Australian entertainer, saying "enough is enough". 
Harris did not give evidence during the trial and therefore could not have his claims tested by cross-examination.
